    Modular Binary Number

    modular_binary_number.Rmd

    Notation

    A modular binary number of dimension \(d\) is noted \((b_{1},b_{2}, \ldots ,b_{d})\), where \(b_{1},b_{2},...,b_{d} \in \mathbb{B}^{1}\). For the sake of simplicity, the simplified notation \(b_{1}b_{2} \ldots b_{d}\) without the parenthesis and comma separators can be used.
    Variables representing modular binary numbers may be noted \(B^{d}\) with dimension \(d \in \mathbb{N}, d > 0\). When several variables are used, subscript notation may be used and noted \(B^{d}_{i}\).

    Definition

    In the context of the haricot package, a modular binary number of dimension \(d\) noted \(B^{d}\) is defined as an ordered set of \(d\) elements of \(\mathbb{B}^1\). By definition, \(B^{d} \in \mathbb{B}^{d}\).

    Formal Definition

    Let the modular binary number dimension \(d\) be a natural number greater than 0: \(d \in \mathbb{N}, d > 0\).
    Let \(B_{d}\) be an ordered n-tuple set \((b_{1}, b_{2}, ..., b_{d})\) where \(b_{1}, b_{2}, ..., b_{d} \in \mathbb{B}^{1}\).
    To designate such n-tuples, we will use the word modular binary number.
    The modular property will be defined later.

    Samples

    \[ B^{1} = 0, B^{1} \in \mathbb{B}_{4} \]

    \[ B^{1} = 1, B^{1} \in \mathbb{B}_{4} \]

    \[ B^{4} = 0000, B^{4} \in \mathbb{B}_{4} \] \[ B^{4} = 1010, B^{4} \in \mathbb{B}_{4} \] \[ B^{6} = 000011, B^{6} \in \mathbb{B}_{6} \] \[ B^{6} = 101010, B^{6} \in \mathbb{B}_{6} \] \[ B^{9} = 111000111, B^{9} \in \mathbb{B}_{9} \]
